revision.text:
The '''CIOB Complex Projects Contract''' '''2013''' was a form of construction and engineering contract, developed by the [[Chartered Institute of Building]] (CIOB). Its formal name was the 'Contract for Use with Complex Projects, First Edition 2013'.
In November 2015, the Complex Projects Contract was updated by the Chartered Institute of Building in response to feedback from the industry. Despite effectively being a second edition, it was renamed the Time and Cost Management Contract 2015 (abbreviated to TCM15) to reflect the core strengths of the contract.
== Launch == Based upon extensive research carried out by the [[Chartered Institute of Building|CIOB]],<ref>"Managing the Risk of Delayed Completion in the 21st Century" http://www.ciob.org/time-management</ref> the contract was formally launched on 23 April 2013. The contract was billed as the world’s first contract specifically aimed at the management of time in complex construction and engineering projects.<ref>"The CIOB Complex Projects Contract 2013, by Keith Pickavance " http://www.thenbs.com/pdfs/NBS-NationlC&LReport2013-single.pdf{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at p.22.</ref> The authors also stated that it was the first form to follow the Society of Construction Law Delay and Disruption Protocol,<ref>"The Society of Construction Law Delay and Disruption Protocol, 2002" {{cite web |url=http://www.scl.org.uk/scl-delay-and-disruption-protocol |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507001236/http://www.scl.org.uk/scl-delay-and-disruption-protocol |archivedate=2014-05-07 |df= }}</ref> and that it was also the first standard form contract to cater for [[Building Information Modelling]] (BIM) and the future of collaborative design.
==Purpose== It is suited for works of high value or complexity, major real estate projects and engineering or infrastructure projects. It is not suited to simpler works, those of short duration or with inexperienced clients /contractors. It anticipates Special Conditions for the particular requirements of each project and if using construction management as the procurement method, it cannot be used without the appropriate terms being included in the Special Conditions.
CPC2013 is designed for use by companies and public authorities in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and in any other country where works comprise complex building and / or engineering, which cannot reasonably be expected to be managed intuitively. It can be used where the contractor is expected to construct only that designed by or under the direction of the client with traditional drawings, specification and/or [[bills of quantities]], or BIM, or on projects which require a contractor’s design in part, or for [[design-build]] projects in which the contractor designs the whole of the works with or without an employer’s reference design.
The contract requires a collaborative approach to the management of design, quality, time and cost. The working schedule, planning method statement and progress records (which are to be inspected and accepted by a competent project time manager and independently audited for [[quality assurance]]) are at the core of management. They are the tools by which all time and time-related cost issues are to be determined and are to conform with the standards required by the conditions, appendices and the CIOB’s Guide to Good Practice in the Management of Time in Complex Projects.<ref>"The Guide to Good Practice in the Management of Time in Complex Projects", Chartered Institute of Building, Wiley Blackwell 2010, {{ISBN|978-1-4443-3493-7}}</ref>
==Collaboration== In order to promote collaboration and to ensure transparency of data, schedule and database submittals are to be made in native file format either by maintenance of the material in a common data environment or transfer by a [[file transfer protocol]] to all having a continuing design, administrative, or supervisory role, who are identified as Listed Persons. The contract also requires the appointment of a Contract Administrator to carry out administrative functions during the course of construction, a Project Time Manager to advise on time related matters, a Valuer to advise on cost matters, a Design Coordination Manager to manage the integration of the Contractor's design, and a Data Security Manager to supervise and maintain the integrity and security of digital communications.
==Risk management== Central to the philosophy of the Complex Projects Contract is its approach to transparency in risk management. CPC2013 provides for both the owner and contractor each to identify one or more time [[contingency allowance]], which each can use as it wishes to manage its own risks. Unusually for a standard form construction contract, it defines [[Float (project management)|"float]]" and provides that if either party creates free float or total float as a result of its own improvement of progress, that party may keep the created float as its own contingency. Additional powers are provided in CPC2013 to enable the construction project's developer, following consultation, to instruct acceleration, recovery and changes in resources sequences and logic in order to manage its risks contemporaneously.
==Time management==
CPC2013 is distinctive in taking a prescriptive approach to the management of time and associated cost risk and combining [[critical path method|critical path]] network techniques with resource-based planning. The time model, referred to as the Working Schedule, combines a high-density, short-term look-ahead similar in concept to that used in [[agile software development]] with medium and long-term lower density schedule along the lines of that used in the [[waterfall model]] planning technique, the whole being revised regularly on the [[Rolling Wave planning]] principle. In the short-term look-ahead, the logic is to be resource and location-related, instead of activity based, as it is in waterfall. The agile part of the schedule is to have its activity durations calculated by reference to the resources to be applied and their expected productivity.
==Cost management== The activities in the Working Schedule are also to be valued so that the Working Schedule also functions as the [[pricing schedule]] to predict current value for the purposes of interim payment and the ultimate out-turn cost for cost risk management purposes.
==Progress records== Progress is required to be recorded in a [[database]] identifying, at specified intervals, the resources used, productivity achieved and [[earned value]]. Apart from being the source data for subsequent progress update of the schedule, the database also serves for [[benchmarking]] productivity achievable for quality assurance of the schedule and future planning.
==Dispute resolution== The emphasis of CPC2013 is on contemporaneous Issue Resolution by an appropriate [[expert]]. CPC2013 it also provides for an escalating Dispute Resolution procedure, embracing [[negotiation]], [[mediation]], [[adjudication]] and [[arbitration]]. Where issues are required to be determined by Issue Resolution within a certain timescale, if the procedure is not invoked there are deeming provisions which determine the outcome of an issue. If Dispute Resolution is required, the expert, adjudicator or arbitrator are either those named in the contract or, in default, they are appointed by the Academy of Experts in London<ref> http://www.academyofexperts.org/ </ref> or the CIOB. The default adjudication rules are those of the Scheme for Construction Contracts<ref> http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2011/2333/contents/made</ref> and the default arbitration procedure is that of the [[London Court of International Arbitration]].
==Ancillary publications== A back-to-back Consultancy Appointment and Subcontract, both of which followed the same principles of time and cost risk management, were published in November 2015 as part of the Time and Cost Management Contract 2015 suite.
== Industry reception == A number of reviews and commentaries have been written on the subject of the Complex Projects Contract. Some have criticized the complexity of the contract itself .<ref>"Complex Projects Contract 2013 - A complex solution for a complex problem" http://www.nabarro.com/Downloads/Construction-newsletter-October-2013.pdf</ref> <ref>"Speechly Bircham: The New CIOB Complex Projects Contract: What you need to know" http://www.speechlys.com/knowledge-centre/knowledge-centre/publications/real-estate-and-contruction-and-engineering/the-new-ciob-complex-projects-contract-what-you-need-to-know.aspx</ref> whereas others have noted the benefits of the clear language, and have commented on the incorporation of its positive features.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.scl.org.uk/ciob-complex-projects-contract-2013 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150313171752/http://www.scl.org.uk/ciob-complex-projects-contract-2013 |archivedate=2015-03-13 |df= }} </ref> <ref>"Navigant Consulting, Inc., Construction Forum Issue 8,The New CIOB Contract For Use On Complex Projects, by Jeremy Glover," http://www.navigant.com/~/media/WWW/Site/Insights/Construction/IFH%20Winter%202013/CON_IH_NewCIOBContractForUseOnComplexProjects_TL_1213%20final.ashx,</ref><ref>Fenwick Elliott LLP, Insight Issue No.33 “The Complex Project Projects Contract 2013” http://www.fenwickelliott.com/files/insight_issue_33.pdf</ref><ref>Practical Law Construction Blog “CIOB’s Contract for use with Complex Projects: take the plunge!” http://construction.practicallaw.com/blog/construction/plc/?p=1612</ref><ref>"FTI Consulting: James Myers Discusses the New CIOB Complex Projects Contract" {{cite web |url=http://www.fticonsulting-asia.com/global2/case-law/james-myers-of-fti-consulting-discusses-the-new-ciob-complex-projects-contract.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521032618/http://www.fticonsulting-asia.com/global2/case-law/james-myers-of-fti-consulting-discusses-the-new-ciob-complex-projects-contract.aspx |archivedate=2014-05-21 |df= }}</ref> Reviews published have consistently commented that it will be necessary for the contract to be tested on a live project before the effectiveness can be proven.
==External links== * [http://www.ciob.org/time-management/ CIOB Time Management's website] * [http://www.ciob.org/tcm CIOB Time and Cost Management Contract 2015's website]

page.title: Cultural influence of the September 11 attacks

revision.text:
The cultural influence of the [[September 11 attacks]] (9/11) has been profound and long-lasting. The impact of 9/11 has extended beyond geopolitics into society and culture in general. Immediate responses to 9/11 included greater focus on home life and time spent with family, higher church attendance, and increased expressions of patriotism such as the flying of [[American flags]].{{cite book|author=Bernardo J. Carducci|title=The Psychology of Personality: Viewpoints, Research, and Applications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1gJPXv5wQbIC&pg=PA200|accessdate=2012-01-16 |date=February 20, 2009|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-1-4051-3635-8|pages=200–}} The radio industry responded by removing certain songs from playlists, and the attacks have subsequently been used as background, narrative or thematic elements in [[List of audiovisual entertainment affected by the September 11 attacks|film, television, music and literature]]. Already-running television shows as well as programs developed after 9/11 have reflected [[post-9/11]] cultural concerns.{{cite book | last1 = Quay | first1 = Sara | last2 = Damico | first2 = Amy | title = September 11 in Popular Culture: A Guide | publisher = [[Greenwood Publishing Group]] | date = September 14, 2010 | isbn = 978-0-313-35505-9}} [[9/11 conspiracy theories]] have become social phenomena, despite lack of support from scientists, engineers, and historians.{{cite journal|title=9/11 conspiracy theories won't stop|first=Joshua|last=Norman|date=September 11, 2011|journal=CBS News|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/09/11/national/main20104377.shtml|publisher=CBS Corporation}} 9/11 has also had a major impact on the religious faith of many individuals; for some it strengthened, to find [[consolation]] to cope with the loss of loved ones and overcome their grief; others started to question their faith or lost it entirely, because they [[problem of evil|could not reconcile it]] with their view of religion.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/29/september-11-challenged-faith_n_941017.html|title=After 9/11, Some Run Toward Faith, Some Run The Other Way|author=Huffington Post|date=August 29, 2011|accessdate=2013-04-06}}{{cite news |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/faith/questions/god.html|title=Faith and Doubt at Ground Zero – The Question of God|author= PBS Frontline|accessdate=2013-04-06}} The culture of the United States succeeding the attacks is noted for heightened security and an increased demand thereof, as well as [[paranoia]] and [[anxiety (mood)|anxiety]] regarding future terrorist attacks that includes most of the nation. Psychologists have also confirmed that there has been an increased amount of national anxiety in commercial air travel.{{cite web |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/articles/200201/anxiety-after-911 |title=Anxiety After 9/11 |author=Brad Schmidt, Ph.d. |accessdate=2013-10-11}} Due to the significance of the attacks, media coverage was extensive, including disturbing live pictures, and prolonged discourse about the attacks in general, resulting in [[iconography]] and greater meaning associated with the event. [[Don DeLillo]] called it "the defining event of our time".{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The attacks spawned a number of catchphrases, terms, and slogans, many of which continue to be used more than a decade later. ==Media response== Through an endless reproductions in [[mass media]] and [[popular culture]] the attacks have an important cultural meaning for many people: "The attacks percolate as a central theme or historical backdrop in countless works of art, which bear witness to the complexity of 9/11 as historical, political, and media event, and contribute to the negotiation of its cultural meaning." Bauder-Begerow, Irina; Stefanie Schäfer. "Learning 9/11." ''Learning 9/11''. Ed. Bauder-Begerow, Irina; Stefanie Schäfer. Memmingen: Winter Verlag, 2011. {{ISBN|978-3-8253-5941-6}} Regarding the attacks of 9/11 and [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]] Arthur G. Neal said:
''"[W]e create the world through our perceptions of it and seek to maintain that world in a manner consistent with our beliefs about it. It is through such symbolic constructions that we are provided with usable frameworks for shaping our memories and organizing them into coherent systems of meaning."''Neal, Arthur G. ''National Trauma and Collective Memory: Extraordinary Events in the American Experience''. M.E. Sharpe: London, 2005. {{ISBN|978-0765615824}}
=== Influence on Comic Books === American comic books have always carried patriotic tones, especially during the cold war—perhaps the most notable example is the character [[Captain America]]. 9/11 shifted the political climate and with it re-centered the public's attention on Muslims. Perhaps the most mainstream example of the influence 9/11 had on comic books is Iron Man, who was previously an anti-communist crusader; his canon was rewritten in comics after 9/11 and in the widely popular 2008 film [[Iron Man]]. In the film billionaire [[Tony Stark]] learns his weapons were sold without his knowledge to various terrorist groups after he was kidnapped and tortured in Afghanistan.Pumphrey, N 2016, 'Avenger, Mutant, or Allah: A Short Evolution of the Depiction of Muslims in Marvel Comics', Muslim World, 106, 4, pp. 781-794, Academic Search Complete, EBSCOhost, viewed 16 November 2017 ==Symbolism== The September 11 attacks gained an iconographic meaning. This was due to the fact that the Twin Towers of the [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]] in [[New York City]] were portrayed as symbolic buildings representing American financial power, and [[the Pentagon]] in [[Arlington County, Virginia]] was portrayed as a symbolic building representing American military power. Backed up by the media and literature, many people see 9/11 as an attack on the economic and military power of America.Hartwig, Marcel. ''Die Traumatisierte Nation?''. Transcript Verlag: Bielefeld, 2011. {{ISBN|978-3-8376-1742-9}} Furthermore, the attacks are often pictured as a symbol for an era of war and terrorism. ==Jargon inspired by 9/11== ;Nine-eleven or 9/11: in the U.S. date notation for September 11. The practice of referring to ominous dates through this shorthand has continued, for example, with 7/7 for the [[2005 London bombings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bing.com/images/search?q=nine-eleven|title=nine-eleven - Bing Images|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://history.librarypoint.org/taxonomy/term/3023|title=Nine Eleven|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107010756/http://history.librarypoint.org/taxonomy/term/3023|archivedate=2015-11-07|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.911forum.org.|title=911forum.org|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119154711/http://911forum.org/|archivedate=2015-11-19|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://9-11commission.gov/|title=National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States|publisher=}}{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/series/9-11-the-10th-anniversary | location=London | work=The Guardian | date=1 September 2011}} Even in English-speaking countries which typically use a different date format to The U.S. "month/day/year", the event is still commonly referred to as "Nine-eleven". For example, "Nine-eleven" will tend to be used in everyday speech in the United Kingdom, despite how British people would otherwise write September 11th as "11/09". ;Pre-9/11 and [[Post-9/11]]: Terms used to describe the period of time and the state of the world before and after the attack, regarding 9/11 as an [[Epoch (reference date)|epoch]]. They are often used to denote foreign policy and domestic security measures as they existed before or after the attacks. ;[[Ground zero|Ground Zero]]: ''Ground zero'' is a generic term for the point on the Earth's surface closest to a detonation. Capitalized, it is shorthand for the World Trade Center site; used, for example, in "Ground Zero mosque", a pejorative for the [[Park51|Cordoba House or Park51]] Islamic center. ;The Bathtub:the excavated foundations of the World Trade Center. Although not a new term, it gained prominence during rescue, cleanup and ongoing reconstruction efforts.{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/5837791/how-new-york-city-built-a-massive-underground-transit-station-in-the-wtcs-footprints|title=How New York City Built a Massive $3.8 Billion Underground Transit Station in the WTC's Footprints|author=Andrew Tarantola|publisher=Gawker Media|work=Gizmodo}} ;[[Rescue and recovery effort after the September 11 attacks#Debris removal|The Pile]]: the rubble of the collapsed World Trade Center.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=91609&page=1|title=The Pit and The Pile: Ground Zero Is Gone|author=ABC News|work=ABC News}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/11/11/magazine/the-way-we-live-now-11-11-01-on-language-ground-zero.html | work=The New York Times | first=William | last=Safire | title=The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: On Language; Ground Zero | date=11 November 2001}}{{cite web|url=http://www.policeone.com/police-heroes/articles/125496-Ex-NYPD-officers-remember-the-pile/|title=Ex-NYPD officers remember "the pile"|work=PoliceOne}} ;[[Jumper (suicide)|Jumper]]:A [[jumper (suicide)|jumper]] is someone who commits [[suicide]] by jumping from a height. It is unclear which of the "jumpers" seen falling from the WTC had jumped and which fell while trying to climb to safety.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2035720/9-11-jumpers-America-wants-forget-victims-fell-Twin-Towers.html|title=9/11 jumpers: America wants to forget victims who fell from Twin Towers|last=Leonard|first=Tom|date=11 September 2011|work=[[Mail Online]]|accessdate=20 November 2012|location=London}} The medical examiner's office ruled [[homicide]] for [[Casualties of the September 11 attacks#World Trade Center|all bodies]], unable to distinguish jumpers from those who died inside the towers.{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/sept11/2002-09-02-jumper_x.htm|title=Desperation forced a horrific decision|last=Cauchon|first=Dennis|author2=Martha Moore |date=2 September 2002|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=20 November 2012}} "[[The Falling Man]]" is an iconic photograph of a jumper. ;"[[Let's roll]]": reported to have been uttered by [[United Airlines Flight 93|Flight 93]] passenger [[Todd Beamer]] shortly before he and fellow passengers apparently rushed the cockpit.[[Let's roll]] (Note: Wikipedia is not ordinarily used as a reference; however this article is well-referenced and ''its references'' support the statement here.) ;[[Force Protection Condition|FPCON Delta]]: the highest state of terrorist alert issued by the [[Military of the United States|U.S. Armed Forces]] === Media slogans === Various slogans and captions were employed by media outlets to [[brand]] coverage of the September 11th terrorist attack, its after effects, and the [[United States|U.S.]] government response. The slogans for American media were typically positioned on the bottom third of television broadcasts, or as banners across the top of newspaper pages. Designs typically incorporated a [[Patriotism|patriotic]] red, white, and blue motif, along with an explicit graphic of the American flag. Examples include: * "America Attacked", "A Nation United" ([[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]) * "Attack on America" ([[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]]) * "A Nation Challenged", "Day of Terror", "Portraits of Grief" ([[The New York Times]]) * "America's New War", "War Against Terror", "America under Attack" ([[CNN]]) * "War on Terror" ([[Fox News]]) * "America on Alert", "America under Attack" ([[MSNBC]]) * "The Second Pearl Harbor" ([[Honolulu Advertiser]]) * "War on America" ([[The Daily Telegraph]]) === U.S. government terms === * '''[[War on Terrorism]]''' (also '''Global War on Terror''') refers to the political response from the U.S. Government to the attacks of 9/11 and includes the invasions of [[Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq]], the color-coded national threat condition reporting system, the [[USA PATRIOT Act|Patriot Act]], and the prison camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.{{cite news |author=Eric Schmitt |author2=Thom Shanker |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/26/politics/26strategy.html?_r=0 |title=U.S. Officials Retool Slogan for Terror War |work=[[New York Times]] |date=26 July 2005 |accessdate=8 January 2015 }} * '''[[Operation Enduring Freedom|Enduring Freedom]]''' – name for U.S.-led military response in Afghanistan, Philippines, Horn of Africa, and Trans Sahara. * '''Infinite Justice''' – original name for U.S.-led military response, dropped after religious overtones were pointed out by a reporter at a press briefing == See also == * [[Artwork damaged or destroyed in the September 11 attacks]] * [[Discrimination and National Security Initiative]] * [[List of cultural references to the September 11 attacks]] * [[List of entertainment affected by the September 11 attacks]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://archive.org/details/911/day/20010911#/ Live reporting of various TV stations on 9-11] {{Sept11}} [[Category:Aftermath of the September 11 attacks]] [[Category:Cultural impact|9/11]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Five times a year | circulation = | category = Cultural magazine | company = | publisher = El Ciervo 96, S.A | founder = Lorenzo Gomis
Roser Bofill | founded = 1951 | firstdate = | finaldate = | country = [[Spain]] | based = [[Barcelona]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | website = [https://www.elciervo.es/ ''El Ciervo''] | issn = | oclc = 830988963 }} '''''El Ciervo''''' (meaning ''The Deer'' in English) is a [[Spanish language]] cultural and opinion magazine based in [[Barcelona, Spain]]. Founded in 1951 the magazine is one of the longest running independent cultural and political magazines in the country.{{cite news|title=Journal Info. El Ciervo|url=https://www.jstor.org/journal/elciervo|accessdate=5 February 2017|work=JSTOR}} ==History and profile== ''El Ciervo'' was established in 1951.{{cite book|title=Western Europe 2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M9QYndAPmuQC&pg=PA593|accessdate=5 February 2017|date=30 November 2002|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-152-0|page=592}}{{cite news|title=El Ciervo|url=http://www.revistasculturales.com/revistas/14/el-ciervo/|accessdate=5 February 2017|work=Revistas Culturales}} The first issue appeared in [[Barcelona]] in late June 1951. Lorenzo Gomis was the cofounder and one of the former directors.{{cite journal|author=F. J. Castilhos Karam|title=In Memoriam|journal=Brazilian Journalism Research|date=2006|url=https://bjr.sbpjor.org.br/bjr/article/viewFile/74/75|volume=2|issue=1|accessdate=5 February 2017}}{{cite news|title=Lorenzo Gomis, fundador de la revista El Ciervo|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2006/01/01/obituarios/1136119829.html|accessdate=5 February 2017|work=El Mundo|date=3 January 2006|location=Barcelona|language=Spanish}} His wife journalist Roser Bofill is the other cofounder. The magazine is the brainchild of Claudio Colomer Marqués, director of the newspaper ''El Correo Catalán''.{{cite news|author=Jordi Amat|title=Por donde se mueve 'El Ciervo'|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/libros/20120606/54304746729/por-donde-se-mueve-el-ciervo.html|accessdate=5 February 2017|work=La Vanguardia|date=6 June 2012|language=Spanish}} He also financed the magazine for the first five years. The magazine was formerly published on a monthly basis.{{cite journal|author=Andrew Dowling|title=For Christ and Catalonia: Catholic Catalanism and Nationalist Revival in Late Francoism|journal=Journal of Contemporary History|date=2012|volume=47|issue=3|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0022009412441648|accessdate=6 February 2017}} It is published by El Ciervo 96, S.A, five times a year. The magazine has no ties with media groups or political parties. During the formative years the magazine adhered to [[Liberal Christianity|liberal Christian]] stance, but later it abandoned it. At the same time the magazine was one of the media outlets, which expressed a culture of [[dissidence]].{{cite book|author=Marvin D'Lugo|title=Guide to the Cinema of Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hVIyvw7_8BkC&pg=PA13|accessdate=5 February 2017|year=1997|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-29474-7|page=13}} By the late 1950s the magazine began to adopt a progressive stance. The headquarters of the magazine was seized by the Francoist forces. During the 1970s it supported the democratic transition to end [[Francoist Spain|Francoist era]].{{cite news|title=La revista cultural 'El Ciervo' presenta un libro que resume sus 40 años|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1992/06/10/cultura/708127206_850215.html|accessdate=5 February 2017|work=El Pais|date=10 June 1992|location=Madrid|language=Spanish}} On 4 July 1972 the Adolfo Hitler Commando invaded the headquarters of the magazine.{{cite web|title=Cronica D'Una Mirada: Clandestine Filmmaking Under Franco, 1960 - 1975|url=https://pragda.com/cronica/material/Cronica_Guidebook_Eng.pdf|work=Pragda|accessdate=5 February 2017|page=33}} Following the transition the magazine reduced its interest in politics, and mostly covered cultural issues. ''El Ciervo'' covers articles about all topics related to society. Enrique Sordo was among the early contributors.{{cite book|author=Mónica Olivares Leyva|title=Graham Greene’s Narrative in Spain: Criticism, Translations and Censorship (1939-1975)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cp7WCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA130|accessdate=5 February 2017|date=13 October 2015|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=978-1-4438-8471-6|page=130}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== {{Official website|https://www.elciervo.es/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ciervo}} [[Category:1951 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Catalan magazines]] [[Category:Cultural magazines]] [[Category:Francoist Spain]] [[Category:Independent magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1951]] [[Category:Media in Barcelona]] [[Category:Spanish political magazines]] [[Category:Spanish-language magazines]] [[Category:Spanish monthly magazines]]

{{ infobox alternative medicine | name = Facilitated communication | image = Facilitated communication PBS.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Facilitated communication shown in a 1993 PBS documentary, in which a disabled person's right hand is helped to move (or simply pulled) by a facilitator across a board showing the alphabet. The image shows a principal criticism of FC: that often the person is not looking at the board, so they cannot really be signing out a message. | claims = Disabled people may be able to communicate by pointing at letters or with a keyboard if physically held and assisted by an expert facilitator. | topics = [[Alternative medicine]] | origyear = Late 20th century | origprop = [[Rosemary Crossley]] | laterprop = [[Douglas Biklen]] | seealso = | MeshID = }} {{Paranormal}} '''Facilitated communication''' ('''FC'''), '''supported typing''' or '''hand over hand''', is a discredited technique<ref name="Autism Wars">{{cite web |last1=Vyse |first1=Stuart |title=Autism Wars: Science Strikes Back |url=https://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/autism_wars_science_strikes_back |website=Skeptical Inquirer Online |publisher=Skeptical Inquirer |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> used by some caregivers and educators in an attempt to assist people with severe educational and communication disabilities. The technique involves providing an alphabet board, or keyboard. The facilitator holds or gently touches the disabled person's arm or hand during this process and attempts to help them move their hand and amplify their gestures. In addition to providing physical support needed for typing or pointing, the facilitator provides verbal prompts and moral support.<ref name="Facilitated Communication Is a Cult That Won’t Die">{{cite web|last1=Auerbach|first1=David|title=Facilitated Communication Is a Cult That Won't Die|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/medical_examiner/2015/11/facilitated_communication_pseudoscience_harms_people_with_disabilities.html|website=Slate|accessdate=30 November 2015|date=2015-11-12}}</ref> In addition to human touch assistance, the facilitator's belief in their communication partner's ability to communicate seems to be a key component of the technique.
There is widespread agreement within the scientific community and multiple disability advocacy organizations that facilitators, not the person with the communication disability, are the source of all or most messages obtained through FC, by [[Ideomotor phenomenon|guiding]] the arm of the patient towards answers they expect to see or that form intelligible language.<ref name="Why debunked autism treatment fads persist">{{cite web|last1=Lilienfeld|title=Why debunked autism treatment fads persist|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/02/150226154644.htm|website=Science Daily|publisher=Emory University|accessdate=10 November 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Ganz/Katsiyannis/Morin">{{cite journal|last1=Ganz|first1=Jennifer B.|last2=Katsiyannis|first2=Antonis|last3=Morin|first3=Kristi L.|title=Facilitated Communication|journal=Intervention in School and Clinic|volume=54|date=February 2017|pages=52–56|doi=10.1177/1053451217692564}}</ref> Alternatively, the facilitator may hold the alphabet board and move it to the disabled person's finger. Studies asking about things the facilitator cannot know (for example showing the patient but not the facilitator an object) have confirmed this, showing that a facilitator is generally unable to ‘help’ the patient sign out the answer to a question where they do not know what the answer should be.<ref name="An experimental analysis of facilitated communication">{{cite journal|last1=Montee|first1=B B|last2=Miltenberger|first2=R G|last3=Wittrock|first3=D|last4=Watkins|first4=N|last5=Rheinberger|first5=A|last6=Stackhaus|first6=J|title=An experimental analysis of facilitated communication.|journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis|date=1995|volume=28|issue=2|pages=189–200|doi=10.1901/jaba.1995.28-189|pmid=7601804|pmc=1279809}}</ref> In addition, numerous cases have been reported by investigators in which disabled persons were assumed by facilitators to be signing a coherent message while their eyes were closed, or they were looking away from or showing no particular interest in the letter board.<ref name="Making contact with a helping hand">{{cite news|last1=Goldacre|first1= Ben|title=Making contact with a helping hand|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/dec/05/bad-science-ben-goldacre-column|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=10 November 2015|date= 2009-12-05}}</ref>
Some promoters of the technique have countered that FC cannot be clearly disproven by testing, since a testing environment might feel confrontational and alienating to the subject.<ref name="Palfreman, Jon (1993)" /> Because the [[scientific consensus]] is that FC is a [[pseudoscience]] which causes great risk and emotional distress to people with communication disabilities, their families, and their caregivers, the technique is now rejected outside a few fringe groups and organizations, including [[Syracuse University]] in the United States. In 2015 Sweden banned the use of FC in special needs schools.<ref name="SvD Nyheter">{{cite news|title=Criticized method prohibited by the Swedish School Inspectorate|url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/4212415.svd|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=SvD Nyheter|date=23 December 2014}}</ref>
==Overview== Facilitated communication is promoted as a means to assist people with severe communication disabilities in pointing to letters on an alphabet board, keyboard or other device so that they can communicate independently. It also appears in the literature as "supported typing",<ref name="ISAAC Position Statement (2014)">{{cite journal|title=ISAAC Position Statement on Facilitated Communication: International Society for Augmentative and Alternative Communication|journal=Augmentative and Alternative Communication|date=2014|volume=30|issue=4|pages=357–358|doi=10.3109/07434618.2014.971492|pmid=25379709|author1=International Society for Augmentative Alternative Communication}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015--></ref> "progressive kinesthetic feedback",<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /> and "written output communication enhancement".<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)"/> It is somewhat related to the [[Rapid Prompting Method]] (RPM),<ref name="Burling, Stacey (2004)">{{cite news|last1=Burling|first1=Stacey|title=A pacesetting technique style for the autistic. She used the technique on her son. Some doubt the value of her methods.|url=http://articles.philly.com/2004-05-17/news/25382897_1_autistic-children-autistic-disorder-autistic-person|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=May 17, 2004|location=Philadelphia, PA|page=C.1}}</ref> also known as "informative pointing",<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /> which has no evidence of efficacy.<ref name="Wombles, Kimberly (2015)">{{cite journal|last1=Wombles|first1=Kimberly|title=Some fads never die - they only hide behind other names: Facilitated Communication is not and never will be Augmentative Communication|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=18 February 2015|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/loi/tebc20|accessdate=March 18, 2015|doi=10.1080/17489539.2015.1012780|volume=8|pages=181–186|issue=4}}</ref><ref name="AshaLeaderBlog">{{cite web|last1=Travers|first1=Jason|title=The Pseudoscientific Phenom—Facilitated Communication—Makes a Comeback|url=http://blog.asha.org/2015/05/19/the-pseudoscientific-phenom-facilitated-communication-makes-a-comeback/|website=The Asha Leader Blog|publisher=American-Speech-Language-Hearing Association|accessdate=10 April 2016|date=2015-05-19}}</ref><ref name="science20">{{cite web|last1=Wombles|first1=Kim|title=Why Rapid Prompting Method Still Doesn't Pass the Evidence-Based Test|url=http://www.science20.com/countering_tackling_woo/blog/why_rapid_prompting_method_still_doesn’t_pass_evidencebased_test-68146|website=Science 2.0|publisher=ION Publications LLC|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
The person with disabilities, who is often not able to rely on speech to communicate, is referred to as the ''communication partner''. The caregiver, educator or other provider offering physical support to the person with disabilities is called the ''facilitator''. The facilitator holds or gently touches the communication partner's elbow, wrist, hand, sleeve or other parts of the body<ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1990)">{{cite journal|last1=Biklen|first1=Douglas|title=Communication Unbound: Autism and Praxis|journal=Harvard Educational Review|date=1990|volume=60|pages=291–314|doi=10.17763/haer.60.3.013h5022862vu732|issue=3}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015--></ref> while the communication partner points to letters of the alphabet printed on a piece of paper or laminated cardboard,<ref name="Schwiegert, Mary Beth">{{cite news|last1=Schwiegert|first1=Mary Beth|title=Will to succeed Lititz man battles autism - and goes to college|work=Lancaster New Era|date=28 December 2000|location=Lancaster, Pennsylvania|page=D-1}}</ref> letters on an alphabet board, laptop, keyboard or mobile communication device such as an iPad.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" />
The Canon Communicator, a small, portable, lightweight device that printed a tape of letters when activated, was popular with early FC users.<ref name="Biklen, Morton, Gold, Berrigan, Swaminatham (1992)">{{cite journal|last1=Biklen|first1=Douglas|last2=Morton|first2=Mary Winston|last3=Gold|first3=Deborah|last4=Berrigan|first4=Carol|last5=Swaminathan|first5=Sudha|title=Facilitated Communication: implications for individuals with autism|journal=Topics in Language Disorders|date=1992|volume=12|issue=4|pages=1–28|doi=10.1097/00011363-199208000-00003}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015--></ref><ref name="Dillon, Kathleen M. (1993)">{{cite journal|last1=Dillon|first1=Kathleen M.|title=Facilitated Communication, Autism and Ouija|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=1993|volume=17|issue=3|pages=281–287|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Dineen, Janice (1991)">{{cite news|last1=Dineen|first1=Janice|title=How autistic Chloe stunned the medical world|work=Toronto Star|issue=SA2 Edition|date=December 21, 1991|location=Toronto, Ontario|page=A1}}</ref> However, two companies, Crestwood Co. of Glendale, Wisconsin and Abovo Co. of Chicopee, Massachusetts, would later be charged by the [[Federal Trade Commission]] for making "false and unsubstantiated claims" that the device could enable people with [[autism]] and other disabilities to communicate using FC. The companies settled and stopped mentioning FC in their advertising campaigns.<ref name="Boodman, Sandra (1995)">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/wellness/1995/01/17/can-autistic-children-be-reached-through-facilitated-communication-scientists-say-no/0f703028-81ac-4d4a-877e-daf6f98cd0fc/|title=Can autistic children be reached through 'Facilitated Communication'? Scientists say no|date=January 17, 1995|work=The Washington Post|issue=Final Edition|location=Washington, D.C.|page=z01|last1=Boodman|first1=Sandra G.|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref>
Proponents of FC claim that motor issues (e.g., the [[Neurological disorder|neurological condition]] of [[apraxia]]) prevent people with autism from communicating effectively. Although this claim is unsubstantiated (many people with autism have no difficulty pointing to or picking up objects independently, but do exhibit severe communication difficulties characteristic of the disorder),<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /> proponents argue that physical support and touch are necessary components of communicating through FC. Candidates for FC, presumably, "lack confidence in their abilities"<ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1990)" /><ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /> and physical support, purportedly, helps them overcome this obstacle to communication.
The role of the facilitator is depicted by proponents as integral to helping the person with disabilities point to letters (by holding his or her finger or hand), reducing or eliminating uncontrollable arm movements (shaking or flapping), avoiding mistakes in typing, controlling the initiation of movement,<ref name="Jacobson, Mulick, Schwartz (1995)" /> and speaking words aloud.<ref name="Schwiegert, Mary Beth" /> As well as physical support in typing, the facilitator provides verbal prompts and moral support.<ref name="Mangiacasale, Angela">{{cite news|last1=Mangiacasale|first1=Angela|title=New voice: system lets disabled communicate|work=The Ottawa Citizen|issue=Final Edition|date=January 23, 1992|page=D3}}</ref><ref name="Mostert, Mark (2012)">{{cite journal|last1=Mostert|first1=Mark P.|authorlink=Mark Mostert|title=Facilitated Communication: The empirical imperative to prevent further professional malpractice|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=18 June 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=18–27|doi=10.1080/17489539.2012.693840}}</ref><ref name="von Tetzchner, Stephen (1997)">{{cite journal|last1=von Tetzchner|first1=Stephen|title=Historical issues in intervention research: hidden knowledge and facilitating techniques in Denmark|journal=European Journal of Disorders of Communication|date=1997|volume=32|pages=1–18|doi=10.3109/13682829709021453|pmid=9135710|issue=1}}</ref><ref name="Greenbaum, Kurt (1992)">{{cite news|last1=Greenbaum|first1=Kurt|title=Autistic Method Disputed Researcher Says Child Not Helped|work=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=September 27, 1992|location=Fort Lauderdale, Florida|page=8B}}</ref> Along with human touch, the facilitator's belief in their communication partner's ability to communicate is seen to be a key component of the technique.<ref name="Kim, Rose (1992)">{{cite news|last1=Kim|first1=Rose|title=The magic touch keyboard technique helps severely disabled students learn to communicate|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-06-17/news/mn-480_1_severely-disabled-students|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|issue=Home Edition|date=17 June 1992|location=Los Angeles, California|page=3}}</ref><ref name="Green, Gina (1995)">{{cite journal|last1=Green|first1=Gina|title=An ecobehavioral interpretation of the facilitated communication phenomenon|journal=Psychology in Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities|date=Fall 1995|volume=21|issue=2|pages=1–8}}</ref><ref name="Libman, Gary (1992)">{{cite news|last1=Libman|first1=Gary|title=A controversial technique may be the key to providing sufferers with a way to communicate unlocking autism|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-11-17/news/vw-788_1_facilitated-communication|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|issue=Home Edition|date=17 November 1992|page=1}}</ref>
Former facilitator Janyce Boynton, who came to reject the technique after taking part in double-blind trials, later reported that she received training from [[University of Maine]]<ref name="Facilitated Communication—what harm it can do: Confessions of a former facilitator" /><ref name="How facilitators control words" /> that took for granted that the process worked, and that the complexity of facilitation made it hard to realise that messages were coming from her expectations and not from her patients: "When you’re facilitating, you’re so distracted by other things. You’re carrying on conversations, you’re asking and answering questions, you’re trying to look at the person to see if they’re looking at the keyboard...Your brain is so engaged that you lose sight of what’s happening with your hand...that’s what makes it feel like it’s working because the more you practice it, the more the movements feel really fluid.”.<ref name="Facilitated Communication—what harm it can do: Confessions of a former facilitator">{{cite journal|last1=Boynton|first1=Janyce|title=Facilitated Communication—what harm it can do: Confessions of a former facilitator|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=March 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=3–13|doi=10.1080/17489539.2012.674680}}</ref><ref name="Double Talk">{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Michael|title=Double Talk|url=http://dailyorange.com/2016/04/double-talk-syracuse-university-institute-continues-to-use-discredited-technique-with-dangerous-effects/|website=Daily Orange|accessdate=17 March 2018|date=2016-04-11}}</ref><ref name="How facilitators control words">{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Michael|title=How facilitators control words typed in facilitated communication without realizing|url=http://dailyorange.com/2016/04/how-facilitators-control-words-typed-in-facilitated-communication-without-realizing/|website=Daily Orange|accessdate=17 March 2018|date=2016-04-11}}</ref>
==History== The FC movement may be traced back to the 1960s in Denmark where it failed to take hold because of lack of scientific evidence.<ref name="von Tetzchner, Stephen (1997)" /> FC experienced a period of rapid growth and popularity in Australia in the 1970—1980s, largely due to the efforts of special educator [[Rosemary Crossley]].<ref name="Dillon, Kathleen M. (1993)" /><ref name="Alferink, Larry A.">{{cite journal|last1=Alferink|first1=Larry A.|title=Educational Practices, Superstitious Behavior and Mythed Opportunities |journal=Scientific Review of Mental Health Practice|date=Fall–Winter 2007|volume=5|issue=2|pages=21–30}}</ref><ref name="Palfreman, Jon (2012)">{{cite journal|last1=Palfreman|first1=Jon|authorlink1=Jon Palfreman|title=The dark legacy of FC|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=11 May 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=14–17|doi=10.1080/17489539.2012.688343}}</ref><ref name="Well, Judith (1994)">{{cite news|last1=Well|first1=Judith|title=Facilitation: How much of a helping hand? |work=Jerusalem Post|date=March 9, 1994|location=Jerusalem|page=07}}</ref> [[Arthur Schawlow]], a Nobel laureate whose son was autistic,<ref name="Wright, Pearce (1999)">{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Pearce|title=Obituary: How the laser changed our world: Arthur Schawlow|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/1999/may/11/guardianobituaries|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=The Guardian|date=11 May 1999|location=London, England|page=18}}</ref> and [[Douglas Biklen]], then a special education professor from [[Syracuse University]]<ref name="Green, Gina (1994)">{{cite journal|last1=Green|first1=Gina|title=Mental Miracle or Sleight of Hand? |journal=Skeptic|date=1994|volume=2|issue=3 |pages=68–76|accessdate=}}</ref> who observed Crossley's work in Australia,<ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1990)" /> are credited with popularizing FC in the United States in the late 1980s, early 1990s.<ref name="Wright, Pearce (1999)"/><ref name="Dillon, Kathleen M. (1993)" /><ref name="Jacobson, Mulick, Schwartz (1995)">{{cite journal|last1=Jacobson|first1=John W.|last2=Mulick|first2=James A.|last3=Schwartz|first3=Allen A.|title=A History of Facilitated Communication: Science, Pseudoscience, and Antiscience: Science Working Group on Facilitated Communication|journal=American Psychologist|date=September 1995|volume=50|issue=9|pages=750–765|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.50.9.750}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015--></ref> FC has also received attention in many other parts of the world: Canada, Germany, Austria, Finland, France, Italy, the United Kingdom and Asia.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /><ref name="Alferink, Larry A." /><ref name="Gifford, Aaron (2000)">{{cite news|last1=Gifford|first1=Aaron|title=SU professor still pushes to validate his method|work=The Post-Standard|issue=Final Edition|date=October 9, 2000|location=Syracuse, New York|page=B2}}</ref>
Early adopters of the technique praised FC for its apparent simplicity.<ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /><ref name="Kim, Rose (1992)" /><ref name="Green, Gina (1995)" /><ref name="Celiberti, David (2010)">{{cite journal|last1=Celiberti|first1=David |title=Facilitate This: Part 1 of a Two-Part Interview with Dr. James Todd|journal=Science in Autism Treatment|date=Spring 2010|volume=7|issue=2|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Ballon, Diana (1992)">{{cite news|last1=Ballon|first1=Diana |title=A ray of sunshine for the Rain Man. A new technique for communicating with autistic children is being greeted with skepticism by some experts - but the anecdotal evidence is compelling|work=The Globe and Mail |date=April 25, 1992|location=Toronto, Ontario|page=D.8}}</ref> FC was promoted as a "teaching strategy"<ref name="Stengle, Bernice">{{cite news|last1=Stengle|first1=Bernice|title=Michael casts a spell|work=St. Petersburg Times|issue=City Edition|date=5 September 1993|location=St. Petersburg, Florida}}</ref> and not an experimental or even risky technique that required objective evaluation or close monitoring.<ref name="Green, Gina (1995)" /> As early as 1991, however, more than 40 empirical studies published in peer-reviewed journals involving more than 400 people with autism not only failed to demonstrate FC's efficacy, but indicated that any success reported by proponents of the technique was due to facilitator influence.<ref name="MostertActivist">{{cite journal|last=Mostert|first=Mark|authorlink=Mark Mostert|date=2014|title=An Activist Approach to Debunking FC|journal=Research and Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities|volume=39|issue=3|pages=203–210|doi=10.1177/1540796914556779}}<!--|access-date=14 May 2015--></ref> Many researchers attribute facilitator influence, for the most part, to non-conscious movements.<ref name="Spitz, Herman">{{cite book|last1=Spitz|first1=Herman |title=Nonconscious Movements: From Mystical Messages to Facilitated Communication|date=3 February 1997|publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-805-82564-0|url=http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780805825633/|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref><ref name="von Tetzchner, Stephen (2012)">{{cite journal|last1=von Tetzchner|first1=Stephen|title=Understanding facilitated communication: Lessons from a former facilitator - Comments on Boynton, 2012|journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=June 25, 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=28–35 |doi=10.1080/17489539.2012.699729}}</ref> It is thought that facilitators are genuinely unaware that they, not their client or family member, are controlling the communications.<ref name="Boodman, Sandra (1995)" /><ref name=BW>{{cite news|last1=Brasier|first1=L.L.|last2=Wisely|first2=John|title=Abuse case hinges on a keyboard|url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20071218/NEWS03/712180304/Abuse-case-hinges-keyboardWest-Bloomfield|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=McClatchy-Tribune Business News|date=December 18, 2007|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>
In 1994, the [[American Psychological Association]] (APA),<ref name="Rising, Gerry" /><ref name="Riggott, Julie">{{cite journal|last1=Riggott|first1=Julie|title=Pseudoscience in Autism Treatment: Are the News and Entertainment Media Helping or Hurting?|journal=Scientific Review of Mental Health Practice|date=Spring–Summer 2005|volume=4|issue=1|pages=58–60| accessdate=}}</ref> followed by the [[American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry]] (AACAP),<ref name="Riggott, Julie" /> the [[American Speech-Language-Hearing Association]] (ASHA),<ref name="Jacobson, Mulick, Schwartz (1995)" /><ref name=ECE>{{cite news|last1=Emery, Jr.|first1=C. Eugene|title=FC Message Technique for the Handicapped Unproven, experts say *A national group of speech and language experts votes to warn its 80,000 members that tests show facilitated communication lacks scientific validity|work=Providence Journal|date=November 30, 1994|location=Providence, Rhode Island|page=D-09}}</ref><ref name="Duchan, Judith (2001)">{{cite journal|last1=Duchan|first1=Judith F.|last2=Calculator |first2=Stephen |last3=Sonnenmeier|first3=Rae|last4=Diehl|first4=Sylvia |last5=Cumley|first5=Gary D.|title=A Framework for Managing Controversial Practices |journal=Language, Speech, and Hearing Services in Schools|volume=32|pages=133–141|doi=10.1044/0161-1461(2001/011) |pmid=27764404|issue=3 |year=2001}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015 --></ref> and the [[International Society for Augmentative and Alternative Communication]] (ISAAC)<ref name=Schlosser_et_al_2014>{{cite journal|last1=Schlosser|first1=R.|last2=Balandin |first2=S.|last3=Hemsley |first3=B.|last4=Iacono|first4=T.|last5=Probst|first5=P.|last6=von Tetzchner|first6=S.|title=Facilitated Communication and Authorship: A Systematic Review|journal=Augmentative and Alternative Communication|date=2014|volume=30 |issue=4|pages=359–368|doi=10.3109/07434618.2014.971490|pmid=25384895}}</ref> passed a resolution cautioning practitioners against the use of FC, citing lack of scientific evidence.<ref name="Boodman, Sandra (1995)" /> The APA also recommended that information obtained via FC should not be used to confirm or deny allegations of abuse or make diagnostic or treatment decisions.<ref name=BW/><ref name="Mann, Lisa Barrett (2005)">{{cite news|last1=Mann|first1=Lisa Barrett|title=Oscar Nominee: Documentary or Fiction?; Film Resurrects Discredited Autism Tactic|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-2637.html|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=The Washington Post|issue=Final Edition |date=February 22, 2005|page=Health; F01}}</ref><ref name="The Times (July 2000)">{{cite news|title=Facilitated communication not reliable as evidence|work=The Times|date=July 29, 2000|location=London, England}}</ref> In recognition of continued scientific evidence against the technique, other organizations joined suit, passing their own resolutions advising their membership to avoid the technique. A British government report concluded in 1998 that "the phenomenon fails to materialise once facilitator effects have been controlled. It would be hard to justify further research on this".<ref name="Making contact with a helping hand" /><ref name="Educational Interventions for Children With Autism: A Literature Review of Recent And Current Research">{{cite web|last1=Jordan, Jones & Murray|title= Educational Interventions for Children With Autism: A Literature Review of Recent And Current Research|url=http://dera.ioe.ac.uk/15770/1/RR77.pdf|website=Institute of Education|publisher=DfEE|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref>
By 2001 Mark P. Mostert of Regent University School of Education in Virginia Beach, Virginia, reported in the second of his comprehensive reviews of peer-reviewed literature investigating FC that "Facilitated Communication (FC) had largely been empirically discredited as an effective intervention for previously uncommunicative persons with disabilities, especially those with autism and related disorders. Key empirical findings consistently showed that the facilitator and not the client initiated communication."<ref name="Mostert, Mark P. (2010)" />
Many people believed FC had passed its peak,<ref name="Oswald, Donald P. (1996)">{{cite journal|last1=Oswald|first1=Donald P.|title=Book Review: Facilitated Communication: The Clinical and Social Phenomenon. Edited by Howard C. Shane. San Diego, CA: Singular Publishing Group. 1994. pp. 323|journal=Journal of Behavioral Education|date=September 1996|volume=6|issue=3|pages=355–357|jstor=41824137}}</ref> dismissing it as a fad<ref name="Oswald, Donald P. (1996)" /> and characterizing it as pseudo-scientific.<ref name="Wombles, Kimberly (2015)" /><ref name="Normand, Matthew P. (2008)">{{cite journal|last1=Normand|first1=Matthew P.|title=Science, Skepticism, and Applied Behavior Analysis|journal=Behavior Analysis in Practice|date=Winter 2008|volume=1|issue=2|pages=42–49|pmid=22477687|pmc=2846586|doi=10.1007/BF03391727}}</ref> However, despite these findings, FC proponents continued their adherence to the technique, dismissing empirical investigations as irrelevant, flawed or unnecessary, characterizing FC as an "effective and legitimate intervention" in pro-FC literature,<ref name="Mostert, Mark P. (2010)">{{cite journal|last1=Mostert|first1=Mark P.|authorlink=Mark Mostert|title=Facilitated Communication and Its Legitimacy - Twenty-first century developments|journal=Exceptionality|date=2010 |volume=18|pages=31–41|doi=10.1080/09362830903462524|issue=1}}<!--|accessdate=March 18, 2015--></ref> and refusing to change their minds or admit their mistakes.<ref name=MostertActivist /><ref name="Gardner, Martin">{{cite journal|last1=Gardner|first1=Martin |title=Facilitated Communication: A Cruel Farce|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=January–February 2001|pages=17–19 |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Porter, Kayla">{{cite news|last1=Porter|first1=Kayla|title=Awakening the silence|work=McClatchy-Tribune Business News|date=14 August 2007|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> The FC movement retained popularity in some parts of the United States, Australia, and Germany,<ref name="Palfreman, Jon (2012)" /> and continued to be used in many countries {{As of|2014|lc=y}}.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /> Mostert writes:<blockquote>All the newer pro-FC studies operate from the premise that FC works and is a legitimate practice to be used in investigating any number of other phenomena related to people with autism and other related severe communication problems. Such assumptions increasingly morph FC into a valid intervention among readers who are unaware of the empirical dismissal of the intervention and who might not be skilled in distinguishing solid from suspect research. In this regard, it is likely that FC will continue to reinforce the assumptions of efficacy among parents and practitioners. These perceptions will continue to be reinforced by professional organizations such as the Facilitated Communication Institute at Syracuse University, a fairly wide acceptance of FC internationally, and the vacuum created by few if any future solid empirical studies that are likely to dissuade the faithful.<ref name="Mostert, Mark P. (2010)" /></blockquote>
==RPM== {{Main|Rapid prompting method}} Facilitated communication is closely related to the [[rapid prompting method]] (RPM), although proponents of RPM deny similarities with FC because the aide or facilitator in RPM holds the letter board but "does not touch the person typing"<ref name="Chandler, Michael (March 2017)">{{cite news|last1=Chandler|first1=Michael Alison|title=The key to unlock their autistic son's voice|url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/the-washington-post/20170301/281487866131617|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=March 1, 2017|location=Washington, D.C.|page=A.1}}</ref> and that the prompts are "nonspecific."<ref name="Beach, Patrick (January 2008)">{{cite news|last1=Beach|first1=Patrick|title=Understanding Tito|work=Austin Statesman|date=January 20, 2008|location=Austin, Texas|page=J.1}}</ref> However, critics of RPM point out that subtle cuing takes place during RPM that makes it "highly susceptible to facilitator influence."<ref name="Chandler, Michael (March 2017)"/>
Other similarities between RPM and FC include: reluctance or refusal to test facilitator/client pairs in controlled settings (purportedly because the process breaks the trust between the pair), presumed competence, reliance on anecdotal accounts as proof of efficacy, maintenance of practices, techniques and claims that are inconsistent with the known body of work around the behavior and communication skills of individuals with developmental disabilities or proven remediation techniques, claims of extraordinary literacy or intellectual breakthroughs, unconscious verbal or physical cuing by facilitators to obtain the expected responses, inadequate or non-existent protocols to fade supported or facilitated prompts.<ref name="Tostanoski et al (August 2014)">{{cite journal|last1=Tostanoski|first1=Amy|last2=Lang|first2=Russell|last3=Raulston|first3=Tracy|last4=Carnett|first4=Amarie|last5=Davis|first5=Tonya|title=Voices from the past: Comparing the rapid prompting method and facilitated communication|journal=Developmental Neurorehabilitation|date=August 2014|volume=17|issue=4|pages=219–223|doi=10.3109/17518423.2012.749952|pmid=24102487|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Todd, James (Rapid Prompting)">{{cite book|last1=Todd|first1=James|title=Rapid Prompting|journal=Encyclopedia of Autism Spectrum Disorders|pages=2497–2503|doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-1698-3_1896|year=2013|isbn=978-1-4419-1697-6}}</ref>

==The question of authorship== [[File:Anne McDonald Centre.jpg|thumb|The Anne McDonald Centre, a centre for FC use in Melbourne directed by [[Rosemary Crossley]].]] One of the central questions regarding facilitated communication is who is really doing the communicating.<ref name="Jacobson, Mulick, Schwartz (1995)" /><ref name="Libman, Gary (1992)" /><ref name="Porter, Kayla" /> The ultimate goal of using such a technique, as suggested by Stephen Von Tetzchner, professor of psychology at the University of Oslo, is ''genuine ''communication'', in which the messages obtained through FC originate from the person with disabilities'' and are not, in any way, influenced by the facilitator. However, as von Tetzchner also points out, there are two other potential outcomes of FC: # ''automatic communication'', in which the messages are produced by the facilitator without the communication partner's awareness (similar to [[automatic writing]]); and # ''false communication'', in which the messages are consciously produced by the facilitator to further his or her own goals.<ref name="von Tetzchner, Stephen (1997)" />
===Proponents=== Facilitators using the technique reported unexpected literacy skills in people otherwise thought to be nonverbal, illiterate and incapable of learning more than basic life skills.<ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /><ref name="Kim, Rose (1992)" /><ref name="Ballon, Diana (1992)" /> They proposed that FC unlocked the thoughts and feelings of moderately to severely impaired individuals inaccessible by traditional means.<ref name="Dineen, Janice (1991)" /><ref name="Ballon, Diana (1992)" /><ref name="Brown, Molly T. (1992)">{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Molly T.|title=The typed voice helping the nonverbal communicate|work=Buffalo News|date=28 July 1992|location=Buffalo, New York|page=C:1}}</ref><ref name="Vancouver Sun (1991)">{{cite news|title=29-year-old learns to type and disability disappears|work=The Vancouver Sun|issue=2* Edition|date=24 December 1991|location=Vancouver, B.C.|page=E22}}</ref><ref name="Wolff, Jamey (1991)">{{cite news|last1=Wolff|first1=Jamey|title=The Words They Can't Say [Letter]|work=The New York Times|issue=Late Edition (East Coast)|date=3 November 1991|location=New York, New York|page=A.10}}</ref> Naturally, parents reported their joy and excitement upon seeing their child, with his or her facilitator, type "I love you" for the first time.<ref name="Celiberti, David (2010)" /><ref name="Ballon, Diana (1992)" /><ref name="Gardner, Martin" /><ref name="Vancouver Sun (1991)" /><ref name="Emery, C. Eugene (1994b)">{{cite news|last1=Emery Jr.|first1=C. Eugene|title=Helping hand or surrogate mind? For autistics, a ray of hope dimmed by doubts|work=Providence Journal|date=May 8, 1994|location=Providence, Rhode Island|page=A-01}}</ref><ref name="Licht, Nora G.">{{cite news|last1=Licht|first1=Nora felt that people with disabilities were, themselves, able to write books and poetry,<ref name="Occaso, Carla (2007)" /><ref name="Dickerson, Brian (2008)">{{cite news|last1=Dickerson |first1=Brian FC seemed to bring with it the hope of "shattering old beliefs and methods of working with autistics...and opening doors to new beliefs and methods that no one can yet conceive."<ref name="Dineen, Janice (1991)" /><ref name="Mangiacasale, Angela" /><ref name="Greenbaum, Kurt (1992)" />
FC workshops, training materials, newsletters and newspaper accounts of its use contained emotionally compelling stories—alleged breakthroughs using FC—and, often, espoused the sentiment that FC could empower people with disabilities to "speak" for themselves for the first time. These materials, authored by "persuasive, sincere, authoritative-sounding individuals"<ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /><ref name="Gammage, Jeff">{{cite news|last1=Gammage|first1=Jeff|title=An eye for fakes: Exposing the quacks in psychological treatment is a Drexel professor's mission|url=http://articles.philly.com/2004-10-25/news/25389539_1_sick-childrenpseudoscience-evidence-based-approach|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=25 October 2004|location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|page=C.1}}</ref>—university professors, psychologists, speech-language pathologists—helped set up an ideologic mindset that led many well-meaning facilitators into a cognitive trap rife with confirmation bias and self-deception<ref name="Rising, Gerry">{{cite news|last1=Rising|first1=Gerry|title='Miraculous' autism treatment stirs concern|work=Buffalo News|issue=Final Edition|date=8 January 2001|location=Buffalo, New York|page=2B}}</ref><ref name="Todd, James (2012)" /><ref name="Heinrichs, Paul (March, 1991)">{{cite John Haslett (1993)">{{cite news|last1=Cuff|first1=John Haslett|title=Television "Prisoners of Silence: A Shocking look at autism research|work=The Globe and Mail|date=19 October 1993|location=Toronto, Ontario|page=C.4}}</ref> with one of the key assertions being "assume competence on the part of the communication partner without testing that assumption."<ref name="Green, Gina (1995)" /><ref name=ECE/><ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1992)">{{cite journal|last1=Biklen|first1=Douglas|title=Facilitated Communication.|journal=Word of Mouth: A Newsletter Dedicated to Speech & Language in School-age Children|date=December 1992|volume=4|issue=3 |pages=1–12 |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Ackerson, Sandy (1994)">{{cite journal|last1=Ackerson|first1=Sandy|title=Facilitated Communication: A Communication Breakthrough or Breakdown?|journal=Beyond Behavior|date=1994|volume=5 |issue=2|pages=13–16|accessdate=}}</ref>
Guidelines for facilitators also included instructions to prevent errors during facilitation (by pulling back on the communication partner's hand), expect the emergence of hidden skills and sensitive personal information, use anecdotal data to validate authorship, avoid objective scrutiny, and emphasize "facilitated" over spoken communication.<ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /> Through the guise of public opinion and qualitative studies, rather than the systematic gathering of empirical data through quantitative studies,<ref name="TraversVoice">{{cite journal|last=Travers|first=Jason|last2=Tincani|first2=Matt|last3=Lang|first3=Russell|date=September 2014|title=Facilitated Communication Denies People With Disabilities Their Voice|journal=Research and Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities|volume=39|issue=3|pages=195–202|doi=10.1177/1540796914556778}}<!--|access-date=17 May 2015--></ref><ref name="CardinalMaturingFC">{{cite journal|last=Cardinal|first=Donald|last2=Falvey|first2=Mary|date=September 2014|title=Facilitated Communication Denies People With Disabilities Their Voice|journal=Research and Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities|volume=39|issue=3|pages=189–194|doi=10.1177/1540796914555581}}<!--|access-date=17 May 2015--></ref> facilitators were not only convinced of FC's efficacy, but ready to overturn more than 40 years of autism research.<ref name="Oswald, Donald P. (1996)" /><ref name="Cuff, John Haslett (1993)" /><ref name="SingerStandardsofProof">{{cite journal|last=Singer|first=George|last2=Horner|first2=Robert|last3=Dunlap|first3=Glen|last4=Wang|first4=Mian|date=September 2014|title=Standards of Proof: TASH, Facilitated Communication, and the Science-Based Practices Movement|journal=Research and Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities|volume=39|issue=3|pages=178–188|doi=10.1177/1540796914558831}}<!--|access-date=17 May 2015--></ref>
Despite claims from FC promoters that autism is a motor control and emotional (i.e. confidence) problem that can be overcome with physical support,<ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1990)" /><ref name="Green, Gina (1995)" /><ref name="Well, Judith (1994)" /> autism is largely accepted in the academic and clinical arenas as being a neurological problem often accompanied by [[Intellectual disability|intellectual disabilities]]. A core feature of autism is severe communication problems which cannot be overcome simply by supportively holding onto someone's hand.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /><ref name="Calculator, Stephen (1999)" />
Proponents claim that a few individuals using FC have developed the ability to type independently or with minimal support (e.g., a light touch to the shoulder or to the back of the neck).<ref name="Broderick, Kasa-Henderson (2001)">{{cite journal|last1=Broderick|first1=Alicia A.|last2=Kasa-Handrickson|first2=Christi|title="Say just one word at first": The emergence of reliable speech in a student labeled with autism|journal=JASH|date=Spring 2001|volume=26|issue=1 |pages=13–24 |url=http://eric.ed.gov/?id=EJ629415|accessdate=19 March 2015|doi=10.2511/rpsd.26.1.13}}</ref> Facilitators attributing messages obtained through FC to their communication partners have co-authored books, articles and plays. These, seemingly, addressed the miraculous, freeing nature of FC and, purportedly, gave outsiders a glimpse of the inner worlds of people with autism: ''[[Annie's Coming Out]]'' (1980),<ref name="Koppenhofer, Janet (1993)">{{cite journal|last1=Koppenhofer|first1=Janet|last2=Gilmer|first2=Debbie |last3=McElroy|first3=Mary|title=Facilitated Communication: An annotated bibliography|journal=Creating Inclusive Communities: Monograph Series|date=July 1993|volume=1|accessdate=}}</ref> ''The Secret World of Arthur Wold'' (1993),<ref name="Koppenhofer, Janet (1993)" /> ''Out of Silence'' (1994),<ref name="Sachs, Sylvia (1994)">{{cite news|last1=Sachs|first1=Sylvia|title=Family's struggle with autism brings 'Out of Silence' to life|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=27 March 1994|location=Pittsburgh, PA|page=F-5}}</ref> ''In Dark Hours I Find My Way'' (1995),<ref name="Lezard, Nicholas (1995)">{{cite news|last1=Lezard|first1=Nicholas|title=Books: Paperback round-up|accessdate=March 19, 2015|work=The Guardian| date=4 April 1995|location=Manchester, United Kingdom|page=T.005}}</ref> ''Miracles'' (1997),<ref name="Rathbone, Andy (1997)">{{cite news|last1=Rathbone|first1=Andy|last2=Rathbone|first2=Tina|title=For tragic child, only 'Miracles' will do|work=The Press-Enterprise|issue=All Zones Edition|date=August 29, 1997|page=AA.22}}</ref> ''The Mind Tree'' (2003),<ref name="Burling, Stacey (2004)" /> and ''I am Intelligent'' (2012),<ref name="Cardinal and Falvey (2014)">{{cite journal|last1=Cardinal|first1=Donald N.|last2=Falvey|first2=Mary A.|title=The maturing of facilitated communication: A means toward independent communication|journal=Research and Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities|date=September 2014|volume=39|issue=3|pages=189–194|doi=10.1177/1540796914555581}}<!--|accessdate=March 19, 2015--></ref> to name a few.
With their facilitators attending classes, assisting them in typing out class notes, completing homework and taking tests, some people with autism reliant on FC even graduated from high school or college.<ref name="Schwiegert, Mary Beth" /><ref name="Broderick, Kasa-Henderson (2001)" /><ref name="Persaud, Babita (2002)">{{cite news|last1=Persaud|first1=Babita |title=Lifelong Devotion|work=St. Petersburg Times|issue=City & State Edition|date=12 May 2002|location=St. Petersburg, Florida|page=1B}}</ref><ref name="Riede, Paul (1997)">{{cite news|last1=Riede|first1=Paul |title=Autistics join debate over handson technique: Facilitated Communication, pioneered at SU, still has skeptics |work=Syracuse Herald American|date=28 September 1997|location=Syracuse, New York|pages=A1, A14}}</ref><ref name="Palma, Bethania (2006)">{{cite news|last1=Palma|first1=Bethania|title=Helping learning disabled gain a voice|work=Whittier Daily News|date=6 August 2006|location=Los Angeles, California}}</ref> However, these claims of independent typing, to date, are anecdotal and have not been substantiated by objective means.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /><ref name="Wombles, Kimberly (2015)" /><ref name="SPA (2012)">{{cite web|title=Augmentative and Alternative Communication Clinical Guidelines|url=http://www.speechpathologyaustralia.org.au/publications/clinical-guidelines|website=Speech Pathology Australia|publisher=The Speech Pathology Association of Australia Limited|accessdate=March 19, 2015|date=September 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310210835/http://speechpathologyaustralia.org.au/publications/clinical-guidelines|archive-date=2015-03-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Critics=== People more critical of the technique noticed that, while the facilitators were intent on watching the letter board, their communication partners were often distracted, staring off into space, rolling around on the floor while facilitating,<ref name="Greenbaum, Kurt (1992)" /> falling asleep,<ref name="Green, Gina (1995)" /> or otherwise not paying attention.<ref name="Schwiegert, Mary Beth" /><ref name="Stengle, Bernice" /> Sometimes the communication partners spoke words that conflicted with the words being typed. The language structures and vocabulary used by children being facilitated often exceeded what would normally be considered appropriate for their age and experience.<ref name="Palfreman, Jon (1993)">{{cite web|last1=Palfreman |first1=Jon |authorlink1=Jon Palfreman |title=Frontline: Prisoners of Silence|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/programs/transcripts/1202.html|website=PBS.org|publisher=WGBH Educational Foundation|accessdate=March 18, 2015|date=October 19, 1993}}</ref> Supposedly highly competent individuals gave wrong answers to simple questions or information that should have been readily known (e.g. the name of the family dog, the names of family members, the spelling of their own name).<ref name="Biklen, Douglas (1990)" /><ref name=MH021692>{{cite news|author1=Paul Heinrichs|title=Suffering at the hands of the protectors|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/suffering-at-the-hands-of-the-protectors-20090821-esuq|accessdate=October 21, 2015|work=The Sunday Morning Herald|date=February 16, 1992}}</ref> Still others questioned why people with autism who exhibit excellent fine motor skills needed to have physical support from facilitators in order to point to a keyboard while many people with autism type independently.<ref name="Healey, Michelle (2011)">{{cite news|last1=Healey|first1=Michelle|title=New film gives voice to a nearly silent minority|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/LIFE/usaedition/2011-04-07-autism07_ST_U.htm|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=Gannett News|date=6 April 2011|page=ARC}}</ref>
[[Bernard Rimland]], a research psychologist who founded the [[Autism Research Institute]] of San Diego and the [[Autism Society of America]], asked "How is it possible that an autistic kid can pick up the last tiny crumbs of potato chips off a plate but not have sufficient motor coordination to type the letter E?"<ref name="Boodman, Sandra (1995)" /> [[Howard Shane]], director of the Center for Communication Enhancement at Children's Hospital in Boston and an associate professor at Harvard Medical School, finds it "curious that those being facilitated can only create [these] insightful comments" when helped by an assistant.<ref name="Healey, Michelle (2011)" /> Why, when technology allowed people with severe disabilities the opportunity to access independent communication with even the slightest movement (e.g., an eye wink, movement of an eyebrow, a puff of air into a straw), would a facilitator need to hold their hand?<ref name="Palfreman, Jon (1993)" /><ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" />
Researchers familiar with the [[ideomotor]],<ref name="Hyman, Ray (1999)">{{cite journal|last1=Hyman|first1=Ray|authorlink=Ray Hyman|title=The Mischief Making of Ideomotor Action|journal=The Scientific Review of Alternative Medicine|date=Fall–Winter 1999|volume=3|issue=2| url=http://www.quackwatch.com/01QuackeryRelatedTopics/ideomotor.html}}</ref> [[Clever Hans]],<ref name="Spitz, Herman" /><ref name="Wegner, Fuller, Sparrow (2003)">{{cite journal|last1=Wegner|first1=Daniel M. |last2=Fuller|first2=Valerie A. |last3=Sparrow|first3=Betsy|title=Clever hands: Uncontrolled intelligence in facilitated communication|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date=July 2003|volume=85|issue=1|pages=5–19|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.85.1.5|pmid=12872881 }}<!--|accessdate=March 19, 2015--></ref> or [[Ouija]] effect,<ref name="Dillon, Kathleen M. (1993)" /><ref name="Green, Gina (1994)" /><ref name="Riggott, Julie" /><ref name="Gardner, Martin" /><ref name="Scientific Review (2005)" /><ref name="Todd, James (2012)" /><ref name="Dillow, Gordon (1993)">{{cite news|last1=Dillow|first1=Gordon|title=Teacher says method that helps disabled ruined him. Courts: Autism sufferers, using a 'facilitator' to communicate, accused teacher of sexual assault. Charges dropped but he plans to sue for $2.5 million|work=Los Angeles Times|issue=Home Edition|date=24 January 1993 |location=Los Angeles, CA|page=1}}</ref><ref name="Hall, Genae (1993)">{{cite journal|last1=Hall|first1=Genae A. |title=Facilitator control as automatic behavior: a verbal analysis|journal=The Analysis of Verbal Behavior|date=1993| volume=11|pages=89–97|pmid=22477083|pmc=2748555|doi=10.1007/bf03392890|issue=1}}</ref> noticed small movements made by the facilitators; movements of which the facilitator was often unaware. All this raised concerns about authorship, the role facilitators have in communicating through FC, and the time facilitating took away from the pursuit of scientifically proven communication techniques.<ref name="Lilienfeld, Marshall, Todd, Shane (2015)" /><ref name="Mirenda, Pat (2015)">{{cite journal|last1=Mirenda| first1=Pat|title=Comments and a personal reflection on the persistence of facilitated communication| journal=Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention|date=13 January 2015|doi=10.1080/17489539.2014.997427|volume=8|pages=102–110|issue=2}}</ref> Psychologist Adrienne Perry cautioned: "The adult or child with autism is made a 'screen' for a facilitator's hostilities, hopes, beliefs or suspicions" and that "concentrating on this method could deprive people of the chance to learn other skills that would be more useful to them."<ref name="Papp, Leslie (1996)" />
While proponents insist that FC "should never involve guiding a person as he or she attempts to point or type,"<ref name="Gardner, Martin" /> facilitators can and do influence facilitated movements without realizing it. Gina Green, director of research for the New England Center for Autism in Massachusetts, E.K.
