{{redirect-distinguish|Meat-sweet|Sweet meat|Sweetbread|Meat sweats}} {{Multiple issues| {{MEDREF|article|date=November 2012}}{{Primary sources|article|date=November 2012}} {{update|inaccurate=yes|date=July 2011}} {{globalize|date=July 2017}} }} [[Image:Fast food 01 ebru.jpg|thumb|[[Fast food]] is a typical example of food consumed in standard American diet.]]
The '''Western pattern diet''' (WPD) or '''standard American diet''' (SAD) is a modern dietary pattern that is generally characterized by high intakes of [[red meat]], [[processed meat]], [[Convenience food|pre-packaged foods]], [[butter]], [[fried foods]], high-fat [[Dairy product|dairy products]], [[chicken eggs|eggs]], [[refined grain]]s, [[potatoes]], [[Maize|corn]] (and [[High-fructose corn syrup]]) and [[high-sugar drink]]s.<ref name=pmid16469985 /> The modern standard American diet was brought about by fundamental [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] changes following the [[Neolithic Revolution]], and, later, the [[Industrial Revolution]].<ref name=Carrera>{{cite journal|last1=Carrera-Bastos|first1=Pedro|last2=Fontes|last3=O'Keefe|last4=Lindeberg|last5=Cordain|title=The western diet and lifestyle and diseases of civilization|journal=Research Reports in Clinical Cardiology|date=March 2011|pages=15|doi=10.2147/RRCC.S16919}}</ref>
By contrast, a [[healthy diet]] has higher proportions of unprocessed fruits, nuts, vegetables, whole-grain foods, poultry, and fish.<ref name="Hu2002">{{cite journal|last1=Hu|first1=Frank B|date=February 2002|title=Dietary pattern analysis: a new direction in nutritional epidemiology|journal=Curr Opin Lipidol|volume=13|issue=1|pages=3–9|pmid=11790957|doi=10.1097/00041433-200202000-00002}}</ref><ref name="pmid11124751" />
== Elements== [[File:US Food Consumption Over Time.svg|thumb|Food available to Americans since 1910. Consumption of meat, grain, fruits, and vegetables has risen; consumption of dairy has fallen.]] [[File:US Consumption of Meat, Poultry, and Fish.svg|thumb|Consumption of beef in the US has fallen since the 1970s, while chicken consumption has grown dramatically. Fish and pork remain constant.]] This diet is "rich in red meat, dairy products, processed and artificially sweetened foods, and salt, with minimal intake of fruits, vegetables, fish, legumes, and whole grains."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bloomfield|first1=HE|last2=Kane|first2=R|last3=Koeller|first3=E|last4=Greer|first4=N|last5=MacDonald|first5=R|last6=Wilt|first6=T|title=Benefits and Harms of the Mediterranean Diet Compared to Other Diets|journal=VA Evidence-based Synthesis Program Reports.|date=November 2015|pmid=27559560|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0089086/pdf/PubMedHealth_PMH0089086.pdf}}</ref> Various foods and food processing procedures that had been introduced during the Neolithic and Industrial Periods had fundamentally altered 7 nutritional characteristics of ancestral hominin diets: [[glycemic load]], [[fatty acid]] composition, [[Nutrient|macronutrient]] composition, [[micronutrient]] density, [[Acid–base homeostasis|acid-base balance]], [[sodium]]-[[potassium]] ratio, and [[Dietary fiber|fiber]] content.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cordain|first1=L|last2=Eaton|first2=SB|last3=Sebastian|first3=A|last4=Mann|first4=N|last5=Lindeberg|first5=S|last6=Watkins|first6=BA|last7=O'Keefe|first7=JH|last8=Brand-Miller|first8=J|title=Origins and evolution of the Western diet: health implications for the 21st century.|journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition|date=February 2005|volume=81|issue=2|pages=341–54|pmid=15699220|url=http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/81/2/341.long|doi=10.1093/ajcn.81.2.341}}</ref>
The typical American diet is about 50%[[Carbohydrate| carbohydrate]], 15%[[Protein| protein]], and 35% [[fat]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Last |first1=Allen R. |last2=Wilson |first2=Stephen A. |title=Low-Carbohydrate Diets |journal=American Family Physician |volume=73 |issue=11 |year=2006 |pages=1942–8 |url=http://www.aafp.org/link_out?pmid=16770923 |pmid=16770923}}</ref> These macronutrient intakes fall within the [[Dietary Reference Intake|Acceptable Macronutrient Distribution Ranges]] (AMDR) for adults identified by the Food and Nutrition Board of the United States [[Institute of Medicine]] as "associated with reduced risk of chronic diseases while providing adequate intakes of essential nutrients," which are 45-65% carbohydrate, 10-35% protein, and 20-35% fat as a percentage of total energy.<ref name="FNB2005">{{cite book|author=Food and Nutrition Board. Institute of Medicine|title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Energy, Carbohydrate, Fiber, Fat, Fatty Acids, Cholesterol, Protein, and Amino Acids|date=2005|publisher=The National Academies Press|location=Washington, DC|pages=14–15|url=http://www.nap.edu/read/10490/chapter/2#14|doi=10.17226/10490|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> However, the nutritional quality of the specific foods comprising those macronutrients is often poor, as with the "Western" pattern discussed above. [[Polysaccharide|Complex carbohydrates]] such as [[starch]] are believed to be more healthy than the [[sugar]] so frequently consumed in the Standard American Diet.<ref name="Gary Taubes">Gary Taubes, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/17/magazine/mag-17Sugar-t.html?_r=4&pagewanted=all& Is Sugar Toxic?], The New York Times, April 13, 2011</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/gerona/50A.3.B148 |title=Source of Dietary Carbohydrate Affects Life Span of Fischer 344 Rats Independent of Caloric Restriction |year=1995 |last1=Murtagh-Mark |first1=Carol M. |last2=Reiser |first2=Karen M. |last3=Harris |first3=Robert |last4=McDonald |first4=Roger B. |journal=The Journals of Gerontology Series A: Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences |volume=50A |issue=3 |pages=B148–54 |pmid=7743394}}</ref>
A review of eating habits in the United States in 2004 found that about 75% of restaurant meals were from [[Fast food restaurant|fast-food restaurants]]. Nearly half of the meals ordered from a menu were [[hamburger]], [[French fries]], or [[poultry]] — and about one third of orders included a [[Soft drink|carbonated beverage drink]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Lobb |first=Annelena |title=Eating Habits -- A Look At the Average U.S. Diet |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=September 17, 2005 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB112671039063140472 |accessdate=December 1, 2011}}</ref> From 1970 to 2008, the per capita consumption of calories increased by nearly one-quarter in the United States and about 10% of all calories were from [[high-fructose corn syrup]].<ref name="Grist">{{cite web |last=Philpott |first=Tom |title=The American diet in one chart, with lots of fats and sugars |work=Industrial Agriculture |publisher=Grist |date=April 5, 2011 |url=http://www.grist.org/industrial-agriculture/2011-04-05-american-diet-one-chart-lots-of-fats-sugars |accessdate=December 1, 2011}}</ref>
Americans consume more than 13% of their daily calories in the form of [[added sugar]]s. Beverages such as flavored water, soft drinks, and sweetened caffeinated beverages make up 47% of these added sugars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/chapter-2/a-closer-look-at-current-intakes-and-recommended-shifts/#figure-2-3-desc-toggle|title=A Closer Look at Current Intakes and Recommended Shifts - 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines - health.gov|website=health.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref>
Americans ages 1 and above consume significantly more added sugars, oils, saturated fats, and sodium than recommended in the Dietary Guidelines outlined by the Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion. 89% of Americans consume more sodium than recommended. Additionally, excessive consumption of oils, saturated fats, and added sugars is seen in 72%, 71%, and 70% of the American population, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/chapter-2/current-eating-patterns-in-the-united-states/#figure-2-1-desc-toggle|title=Current Eating Patterns in the United States - 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines - health.gov|website=health.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref>
Consumers began turning to [[margarine]] due to concerns over the high levels of [[saturated fat]]s found in butter. By 1958, margarine had become more commonly consumed than butter, with the average American consuming 8.9 pounds of margarine per year.<ref name="ers.usda.gov">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ers.usda.gov/amber-waves/2016/july/butter-and-margarine-availability-over-the-last-century/|title=USDA ERS - Butter and Margarine Availability Over the Last Century|website=www.ers.usda.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref> Margarine is produced by refining vegetable oils, a process that introduces trans elaidic acid not found naturally in food.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cordain|first=Loren|last2=Eaton|first2=S. Boyd|last3=Sebastian|first3=Anthony|last4=Mann|first4=Neil|last5=Lindeberg|first5=Staffan|last6=Watkins|first6=Bruce A.|last7=O'Keefe|first7=James H.|last8=Brand-Miller|first8=Janette|date=February 2005|title=Origins and evolution of the Western diet: health implications for the 21st century|journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition|volume=81|issue=2|pages=341–354|issn=0002-9165|pmid=15699220|doi=10.1093/ajcn.81.2.341}}</ref> The consumption of trans fatty acids such as trans elaidic acid has been linked to [[cardiovascular disease]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Iqbal|first=Mohammad Perwaiz|date=2014|title=Trans fatty acids – A risk factor for cardiovascular disease|journal=Pakistan Journal of Medical Sciences|volume=30|issue=1|pages=194–197|doi=10.12669/pjms.301.4525|issn=1682-024X|pmc=3955571|pmid=24639860}}</ref> By 2005, margarine consumption had fallen below butter consumption due to the risks associated with trans fat intake.<ref name="ers.usda.gov"/>
Vegetable consumption is low among Americans, with only 13% of the population consuming the recommended amounts. Boys ages 9 to 13 and girls ages 14 to 18 consume the lowest amounts of vegetables relative to the general population. Potatoes and tomatoes, which are key components of many meals, account for 39% of the vegetables consumed by Americans. 60% of vegetables are consumed individually, 30% are included as part of a dish, and 10% are found in sauces.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/chapter-2/a-closer-look-at-current-intakes-and-recommended-shifts/#figure-2-3-desc-toggle|title=A Closer Look at Current Intakes and Recommended Shifts - 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines - health.gov|website=health.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref>
Whole grains should consist of over half of total grain consumption, and refined grains should not exceed half of total grain consumption. However, 85.3% of the cereals eaten by Americans are produced with [[refined grains]], where the germ and bran are removed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/chapter-2/a-closer-look-at-current-intakes-and-recommended-shifts/#figure-2-3-desc-toggle|title=A Closer Look at Current Intakes and Recommended Shifts - 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines - health.gov|website=health.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref> Grain refining increases shelf life and softens breads and pastries; however, the process of refining decreases its nutritional quality.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/whole-grains/|title=Whole Grains|date=2014-01-24|work=The Nutrition Source|access-date=2017-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Health concerns== Based on epidemiological studies, compared to a [[healthy diet]], the Western pattern diet is positively correlated with an elevated incidence of [[obesity]],<ref name="pmid11124751" /> death from heart disease, cancer (especially [[colon cancer]]),<ref name="pmid16990408" /> and other "Western pattern diet"-related diseases.<ref name="Gary Taubes" /><ref name="pmid18574045" /> There is an evolutionary mismatch between the ancient physiology of humans and a Western pattern diet; this underlies [[diseases of civilization]], which include [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|Type II diabetes]], [[Epithelium|epithelial cell]] cancers, [[autoimmune disease]], [[osteoporosis]], [[hypertension]], [[coronary artery disease]], and [[obesity]].<ref name=Carrera/> There is also a correlation between a Western pattern diet and an increase in inflammatory diseases, which is particularly evident in relation to fiber and fat-content.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thorburn|first1=AN|last2=Macia|first2=L|last3=Mackay|first3=CR|title=Diet, metabolites, and "western-lifestyle" inflammatory diseases.|journal=Immunity|date=19 June 2014|volume=40|issue=6|pages=833–42|doi=10.1016/j.immuni.2014.05.014|pmid=24950203}}</ref> The high level of [[omega-6 fatty acid]]s compared to [[omega-3 fatty acid]]s in the Western diet is believed to contribute to [[autoimmune]] and [[Inflammation|inflammatory diseases]], as well as [[cancer]] and [[cardiovascular disease]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3181/0711-MR-311 |title=The Importance of the Omega-6/Omega-3 Fatty Acid Ratio in Cardiovascular Disease and Other Chronic Diseases |year=2008 |last1=Simopoulos |first1=Artemis P. |journal=Experimental Biology and Medicine |volume=233 |issue=6 |pages=674–88 |pmid=18408140}}</ref> [[Acne]] is one of the inflammatory diseases which is increased by the Western pattern diet, due to too much [[carbohydrate]]s with high [[glycemic load]] such as [[white sugar|refined sugars]] or [[refined grains|refined starches]], [[milk]] and [[dairy product]]s, and [[trans fat]]s and [[saturated fat]]s, along with a deficiency in [[omega-3 fatty acid]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Melnik |first1=Bodo C. |editor1-last=Weinberg |editor1-first=Jeffrey |title=Linking diet to acne metabolomics, inflammation, and comedogenesis: an update. |journal=[[Clinical, Cosmetic and Investigational Dermatology]] |date=July 15, 2015 |volume=2015:8 |pages=371-88 |doi=10.2147/CCID.S69135 |pmid=26203267 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26203267 |accessdate=25 November 2018 |publisher=[[Dove Medical Press]]}}</ref>
===Crohn's disease and inflammatory bowel disease === A Western pattern diet consisting of [[Sugar|refined sugars]] and polyunsaturated fatty acids has been associated with [[Crohn's disease]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Baumgart|first=Daniel C|last2=Sandborn|first2=William J|date=|title=Crohn's disease|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60026-9|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9853|pages=1590–1605|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)60026-9|via=|year=2012}}</ref> Crohn's disease has its effects on the [[symbiotic bacteria]] within the human gut that show a positive correlation with a Western pattern diet.<ref name=":8" /> Crohn's is an [[inflammatory disease]] that is associated with immunological responses.<ref name=":8" /> Symptoms can range from severe abdominal pain to diarrhea and fever<ref name=":8" /> [[Inflammatory bowel disease]] has shown increased development with the Western pattern diet, and high consumption of sugar and low plant-based intake is directly correlated with an increase Crohn's disease.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Dolan|first=Kyle T.|last2=Chang|first2=Eugene B.|date=2017-01-01|title=Diet, gut microbes, and the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel diseases|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/mnfr.201600129/abstract|journal=Molecular Nutrition & Food Research|language=en|volume=61|issue=1|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1002/mnfr.201600129|issn=1613-4133}}</ref> Inflammatory bowel disease showed no increase in risk factors only in relation to development of disease associated with the Western pattern diet.<ref name=":9" />
=== Obesity === [[File:Obesity country comparison - path.svg|thumbnail|Obesity among various developed countries]] A Western pattern diet is associated with an increased risk of [[obesity]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Kant|first=Ashima K.|title=Dietary patterns and health outcomes|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jada.2004.01.010|journal=Journal of the American Dietetic Association|volume=104|issue=4|pages=615–635|doi=10.1016/j.jada.2004.01.010|year=2004}}</ref> There is a positive correlation between a Western pattern diet and several plasma [[biomarker]]s that may be mediators of obesity, such as [[High-density lipoprotein|HDL cholesterol,]] fasting [[insulin]], and [[leptin]].<ref name=":3" /> Meta-analyses have also shown that, compared to a healthy diet, a Western pattern diet is linked to increased weight gain among females.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Drewnowski|first=Adam|date=2007-01-01|title=The Real Contribution of Added Sugars and Fats to Obesity|url=https://academic.oup.com/epirev/article/29/1/160/443157/The-Real-Contribution-of-Added-Sugars-and-Fats-to|journal=Epidemiologic Reviews|volume=29|issue=1|pages=160–171|doi=10.1093/epirev/mxm011|issn=0193-936X}}</ref> Relative to a diet high in fruits, vegetables, legumes, and fish, a Western diet is associated with increased risk of being [[overweight]] among adolescents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yang|first=Wai Yew|last2=Williams|first2=Lauren T|last3=Collins|first3=Clare|last4=Swee|first4=Chee Winnie Siew|title=The relationship between dietary patterns and overweight and obesity in children of Asian developing countries: A Systematic Review|url=http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=01938924-201210580-00005|journal=JBI Database of Systematic Reviews and Implementation Reports|volume=10|issue=58|pages=4568–4599|doi=10.11124/jbisrir-2012-407|year=2012}}</ref>
=== Diabetes === Several studies have shown that there is a positive correlation between adoption of a Western pattern diet and incidence of [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|type 2 diabetes]] among both men<ref name=":3" /> and women.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Hu|first=Frank B.|date=2011-06-01|title=Globalization of Diabetes: The role of diet, lifestyle, and genes|url=http://care.diabetesjournals.org/content/34/6/1249|journal=Diabetes Care|language=en|volume=34|issue=6|pages=1249–1257|doi=10.2337/dc11-0442|issn=0149-5992|pmid=21617109|pmc=3114340}}</ref> A strong adoption of a Western pattern diet, when coupled with obesity and decreased physical activity, is associated with an especially elevated risk of type 2 diabetes.<ref name=":3" /> In addition, [[genetic predisposition]] to diabetes interacts cooperatively with a Western pattern diet to increase risk of diabetes.<ref name=":4" />
=== Cancer === The Western pattern diet has been generally linked to increased risk for [[cancer]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Fabiani|first=Roberto|last2=Minelli|first2=Liliana|last3=Bertarelli|first3=Gaia|last4=Bacci|first4=Silvia|date=2016-10-12|title=A Western Dietary Pattern Increases Prostate Cancer Risk: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis|journal=Nutrients|volume=8|issue=10|doi=10.3390/nu8100626|issn=2072-6643|pmc=5084014|pmid=27754328|page=626}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Fung|first=Teresa|last2=Hu|first2=Frank B.|last3=Fuchs|first3=Charles|last4=Giovannucci|first4=Edward|last5=Hunter|first5=David J.|last6=Stampfer|first6=Meir J.|last7=Colditz|first7=Graham A.|last8=Willett|first8=Walter C.|date=2003-02-10|title=Major Dietary Patterns and the Risk of Colorectal Cancer in Women|url=http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/215072|journal=Archives of Internal Medicine|language=en|volume=163|issue=3|doi=10.1001/archinte.163.3.309|issn=0003-9926|page=309}}</ref> Meta-analyses have found that [[Diet (nutrition)|diet]] patterns consistent with those of the Western pattern diet are positively correlated with risk for [[prostate cancer]].<ref name=":0" /> Additionally, a 1998 case review found that the Western pattern diet is directly associated to heightened risks for [[colon cancer]] [2]. This conclusion has been verified by several other studies, which also indicate an increased rate of [[Colorectal cancer|rectal cancer]] in cases who maintained a primarily Western pattern diet.<ref name=":1" /> No significant relation has been established between the Western pattern diet and [[breast cancer]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Sánchez-Zamorano|first=Luisa María|last2=Flores-Luna|first2=Lourdes|last3=Angeles-Llerenas|first3=Angélica|last4=Ortega-Olvera|first4=Carolina|last5=Lazcano-Ponce|first5=Eduardo|last6=Romieu|first6=Isabelle|last7=Mainero-Ratchelous|first7=Fernando|last8=Torres-Mejía|first8=Gabriela|date=August 2016|title=The Western dietary pattern is associated with increased serum concentrations of free estradiol in postmenopausal women: implications for breast cancer prevention|journal=Nutrition Research (New York, N.Y.)|volume=36|issue=8|pages=845–854|doi=10.1016/j.nutres.2016.04.008|issn=1879-0739|pmid=27440539}}</ref> [[Breast cancer]] [[epidemiologists]] have found that women with a more Western diet have a nominally increased risk of breast cancer that is not statistically significant.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brennan|first=S. F.|author2=Cantwell, M. M.|author3=Cardwell, C. R.|author4=Velentzis, L. S.|author5=Woodside, J. V.|date=10 March 2010|title=Dietary patterns and breast cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis|journal=American Journal of Clinical Nutrition|volume=91|issue=5|pages=1294–1302|doi=10.3945/ajcn.2009.28796|pmid=20219961}}</ref> A recent study led by the [[National Institutes of Health|National Institute of Health]] indicates that the Western pattern diet can actually lead to increased levels of free [[estradiol]] in women, which has benefits in regards to [[breast cancer prevention]].<ref name=":2" />
=== Heart disease === There are multiple studies associating the Western pattern diet with heart disease.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Baumgart|first=Daniel C|last2=Sandborn|first2=William J|title=Crohn's disease|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60026-9|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9853|pages=1590–1605|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)60026-9|year=2012}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Simopoulos|first=Artemis P.|date=2002-12-01|title=Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Inflammation and Autoimmune Diseases|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07315724.2002.10719248|journal=Journal of the American College of Nutrition|volume=21|issue=6|pages=495–505|doi=10.1080/07315724.2002.10719248|issn=0731-5724|pmid=12480795}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Heidemann|first=Christin|last2=Schulze|first2=Matthias B.|last3=Franco|first3=Oscar H.|last4=van Dam|first4=Rob M.|last5=Mantzoros|first5=Christos S.|last6=Hu|first6=Frank B.|date=2008-07-15|title=Dietary patterns and risk of mortality from cardiovascular disease, cancer, and all causes in a prospective cohort of women|journal=Circulation|volume=118|issue=3|pages=230–237|doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.108.771881|issn=1524-4539|pmc=2748772|pmid=18574045}}</ref> In 2008, the INTERHEART study, funded by the Canadian Institute of Health Research, concluded that risk of a [[myocardial infarction]] is 30% higher for individuals who consume a Western pattern diet than individuals who consume a prudent diet.<ref name=":5" /> A second study conducted in 2008 by ''Circulation'' also concluded that the Western pattern diet increases the risk of [[cardiovascular]] mortality in healthy US women.<ref name=":7" /> With that, meta-analyses and surveys in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology have associated [[cardiovascular disease]] and/or [[Coronary Heart Disease|coronary heart disease]] with refined carbohydrates, sugar-sweetened beverages, and red and processed meats, three major components of the Western pattern diet.<ref name=":6" />
==Prevalence== The western-versus-eastern dichotomy has become less relevant as such a diet is no longer "foreign" to any global region (just as traditional East Asian cuisine is no longer "foreign" to the west), but the term is still a well-understood shorthand in medical literature, regardless of where the diet is found. Other dietary patterns described in the medical research include "drinker" and "meat-eater" patterns.<ref name="pmid16990408" /> Because of the variability in diets, individuals are usually classified not as simply "following" or "not following" a given diet, but instead by ranking them according to how closely their diets line up with each pattern in turn. The researchers then compare the outcomes between the group that most closely follows a given pattern to the group that least closely follows a given pattern.
==History== [[File:FAO kcal his.png|thumb|350px|Changes of food supply (by energy)<ref>FAO [http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/download/FB/FB/E FAOSTAT]</ref><ref>These are supplied energy, intake energy are about 60-80% of supply. FAO estimates food supply of 2700 kcal to be satisfactory.</ref><br>Other area (Yr 2010)<ref>FAO [http://www.fao.org/docrep/004/x3936e/x3936e03.htm Food Security]</ref> * Africa, sub-Sahara - 2170 kcal/capita/day * N.E. and N. Africa - 3120 kcal/capita/day * South Asia - 2450 kcal/capita/day * East Asia - 3040 kcal/capita/day * Latin America / Caribbean - 2950 kcal/capita/day * Developed countries - 3470 kcal/capita/day]]
The Western diet present in today’s world is a consequence of the [[Neolithic|Neolithic revolution]] and [[Industrial revolution]]s.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal|last=Cordain|first=Loren|last2=Eaton|first2=S. Boyd|last3=Sebastian|first3=Anthony|last4=Mann|first4=Neil|last5=Lindeberg|first5=Staffan|last6=Watkins|first6=Bruce A.|last7=O’Keefe|first7=James H.|last8=Brand-Miller|first8=Janette|date=2005-02-01|title=Origins and evolution of the Western diet: health implications for the 21st century|url=http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/81/2/341|journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition|language=en|volume=81|issue=2|pages=341–354|issn=0002-9165|pmid=15699220|doi=10.1093/ajcn.81.2.341}}</ref> The Neolithic revolution introduced the staple foods of the western diet, including domesticated meats, sugar, alcohol, salt, cereal grains, and dairy products.<ref name=":03" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Carrera-Bastos|first=Pedro|last2=Fontes|last3=O'Keefe|last4=Lindeberg|last5=Cordain|date=2011-03-09|title=The western diet and lifestyle and diseases of civilization|url=http://www.dovepress.com/the-western-diet-and-lifestyle-and-diseases-of-civilization-peer-reviewed-article-RRCC|journal=Research Reports in Clinical Cardiology|language=English|volume=2|doi=10.2147/rrcc.s16919|page=15}}</ref> The modern Western diet emerged after the Industrial Revolution, which introduced new methods of food processing including the addition of cereals, refined sugars, and refined vegetable oils to the Western diet, and also increased the fat content of domesticated meats. More recently, food processors began replacing sugar with [[high-fructose corn syrup]].<ref name=":03" />
